predictions.text: Neither of President Trump’s two 2025-12 infrastructure/water-project vetoes will be overridden by Congress (i.e., no successful 2/3 vote in both chambers) by 2026-04-30 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves YES if, by the deadline, Congress has NOT enacted either vetoed bill over the President’s veto (requires recorded 2/3 votes in both House and Senate for at least one of the two vetoed bills). Resolves NO if at least one veto override becomes law by the deadline.
evidence: Recent report: Trump issued first vetoes of his second term, targeting bipartisan infrastructure and water projects, raising funding uncertainty.
monitoring_signals: House/Senate floor schedule and vote notices referencing veto overrides
Congressional Record roll-call votes on veto override motions
White House legislative affairs updates; major-wire coverage (Reuters/AP) confirming override outcome
predictions.rationale: Veto overrides are historically rare and require sustained bipartisan supermajorities; even with bipartisan projects, coordination and political incentives typically favor renegotiation over override.

predictions.text: Venezuela will release at least one U.S. citizen detained in 2025 (publicly identified by U.S. officials or major media as detained) following a publicly acknowledged diplomatic engagement, by 2026-06-30 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves YES if Venezuelan authorities free at least one U.S. citizen detained in 2025 and the release is publicly confirmed by the U.S. government (State Department/White House) or reliably reported by Reuters/AP/NYT/WSJ with attribution to officials, and the reporting cites diplomatic talks/engagement as part of the resolution. Otherwise NO at deadline.
evidence: Recent report: Venezuela detained U.S. citizens amid escalating U.S. pressure, increasing diplomatic risk.
monitoring_signals: U.S. State Department press briefings and consular statements
Venezuelan government announcements; prisoner-release reports
Reuters/AP reporting on backchannel or formal talks; Qatar/other mediators mentioned
predictions.rationale: Detentions often become bargaining chips; partial releases are plausible but not assured given heightened confrontation and domestic political incentives.

predictions.text: The UK will announce a Russia-related sanctions action adding at least 50 oil tankers/vessels (by name/IMO) to its sanctions list in a single package, by 2026-03-31 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves YES if the UK (OFSI/FCDO) publishes an update/press release on the Russia sanctions regime that, in one dated action, newly lists ≥50 vessels (tankers/shipping) with identifiers (name and/or IMO). Otherwise NO by deadline.
evidence: Recent report: a tanker linked to sanctions-evasion infrastructure appears in Russian databases, highlighting opaque oil flows.
monitoring_signals: UK OFSI consolidated list updates and FCDO press releases
Reuters/Bloomberg coverage of 'shadow fleet' sanctions packages
Shipping intel and NGO trackers flagging candidate vessels prior to sanctions
predictions.rationale: Shadow-fleet focus has been rising; vessel-focused packages are administratively straightforward and politically salient for curbing oil revenue circumvention.

predictions.text: U.S. Commerce (BIS) will add at least 5 China- or Hong Kong-based entities to the Entity List in a single rule/action explicitly citing Nvidia GPU smuggling/diversion or 'advanced computing' export-control evasion, by 2026-06-30 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves YES if the Federal Register or BIS announcement shows one dated Entity List action adding ≥5 entities located in China or Hong Kong, and the stated rationale includes diversion/smuggling/evasion tied to advanced computing chips (e.g., Nvidia GPUs) or comparable language. Otherwise NO.
evidence: Recent report: $160M in export-controlled Nvidia chips allegedly smuggled into China, underscoring enforcement gaps.
monitoring_signals: BIS Entity List final rules (Federal Register) and BIS press releases
DOJ/HSI indictments mentioning diversion networks that later correlate with BIS listings
Reuters/Bloomberg reporting on enforcement actions tied to GPU routing through intermediaries
predictions.rationale: Public allegations and strategic sensitivity increase pressure for visible enforcement; Entity List additions are a common, scalable response.

predictions.text: The PBOC will cut either (a) the reserve requirement ratio (RRR) for banks or (b) a key policy rate (7-day reverse repo or 1-year MLF) at least once, by 2026-03-31 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves YES if, by the deadline, the People’s Bank of China announces a reduction in the RRR for at least one broad bank category, or announces a reduction in the 7-day reverse repo rate or 1-year MLF rate. Otherwise NO.
evidence: Recent report: China’s manufacturing PMI expanded for the first time since March, hinting at stabilization but still fragile demand.
monitoring_signals: PBOC official notices; state media (Xinhua) monetary-policy announcements
Market reactions: CNH/CNY moves, bond yield shifts around policy meetings
Economist previews and signaling via PBOC quarterly reports
predictions.rationale: Even with PMI stabilization, policymakers often lean on incremental easing to support confidence, credit transmission, and property/industrial demand.

predictions.text: CME will raise initial margin requirements for at least one major precious-metals futures contract (COMEX gold or COMEX silver) by at least 10% in a single announced change, by 2026-03-31 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves YES if CME Clearing publishes a margin advisory showing an increase of ≥10% to initial margin for COMEX gold or silver futures (any key contract family) effective on a stated date, with the change announced by deadline. Otherwise NO.
evidence: Recent report: CME raised precious-metals margins again; gold and silver fell afterward, illustrating deleveraging effects.
monitoring_signals: CME Clearing margin advisories and SPAN parameter updates
Large moves in gold/silver volatility and open interest
Broker margin notices referencing CME updates
predictions.rationale: If volatility persists or speculative positioning rebuilds, CME often tightens margins; however, repeated hikes in a short window are not guaranteed.

predictions.text: At least one venture-backed European alternative-protein company (excluding insect-farming) that has raised ≥$100 million in disclosed funding will enter formal insolvency/liquidation/administration proceedings, by 2026-12-31 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves YES if a Europe-headquartered alt-protein company (plant-based, cultivated meat, fermentation-derived proteins; excluding insect farming) with ≥$100M disclosed funding is reported by Reuters/FT/Bloomberg/WSJ or a national corporate registry notice as having entered insolvency/liquidation/administration by deadline. Otherwise NO.
evidence: Recent report: Ÿnsect entered liquidation after raising $600M+, signaling tougher capital markets and scaling risk in alternative proteins.
monitoring_signals: Funding-to-burn indicators: down-rounds, missed payroll rumors, supplier disputes
Corporate registry filings (administration/liquidation) in key jurisdictions (UK, France, Germany, Netherlands)
Trade-press reports of plant closures or emergency bridge financing
predictions.rationale: Higher rates and tighter venture funding increase failure risk for capex-heavy food tech; still, consolidation and rescues can prevent formal insolvency.

predictions.text: The Netherlands will issue at least one formal decision blocking or ordering divestment/unwinding of a China-linked acquisition/investment in a Dutch semiconductor or semiconductor-equipment company under national security/investment screening powers, by 2026-12-31 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves YES if the Dutch government (e.g., Minister for Economic Affairs/competent authority) publicly confirms a block, prohibition, or divestment/unwind order for a China-linked stake/acquisition in a Dutch semiconductor or semi-equipment firm, citing security/screening law, by deadline. Otherwise NO.
evidence: Recent report: China criticized the Netherlands over Nexperia decisions, highlighting politicization and regulatory risk in chip supply chains.
monitoring_signals: Dutch government letters to parliament and official gazette publications
Reuters/Bloomberg reports on Vifo Act decisions and semiconductor-linked screenings
Company filings disclosing screening outcomes/conditions
predictions.rationale: Escalating chip geopolitics increases scrutiny, but formal blocks/divestments are relatively rare and often resolved via conditions or quiet restructurings.
